name: SIGMORPHON 2016 Shared Task: Paradigm Completion
body:
### Welcome
The SIGMORPHON 2016 shared task is 
morphological paradigm completion. The goal, roughly
stated, is to fill out a morphological paradigm, 
a nominal or verbal inflection table,
given some incomplete representation of the whole paradigm,
e.g., the lemma or a partial (potentially noisy) set of
slots of the paradigm. This area of computational
morphology has received a flurry of attention recently
in the NLP literature (Dreyer and Eisner (2009), Dreyer and Eisner (2011),
Durett an DeNero (2013), Hulden et al. (2014), Nicolai and Kondrak (2015), _inter alia_).


### Paradigm Completion – A Brief Introduction
In many of the world's languages words change their form to express different syntactic
and semantic relationships in a structured fashion. For instance, English generally overtly marks the plural with a final 
"s", as in "model" → "models". Even for novel words, native speakers are perfectly capable 
of generating the correct inflections (consider "wug" → "wugs"), making these processes
highly productive. The act of modifying word forms to express these relationships is termed _inflection_ (often _conjugation_ when referring to verb and _declension_ when referring to nouns).
In English, this task is relatively uninteresting, e.g., English
substantives only distinguish singular and plural. 
But many of the world's languages
exhibit a high degree of inflection making this a hard computational problem.
In Polish, for example, a single verb can have over a 100 forms! This sort of linguistic
productivity creates data sparsity problems. With this shared task, we hope to
make a dent in our ability to automate this aspect of computational morphology.

### The Languages
In our selection of languages, we have sought a representative
sample of the world's languages (albeit biased to those with rich inflection).
All of the data has been scraped from Wiktionary and undergone additional
processing at the [Center for Language and Speech Processing](http://www.clsp.jhu.edu/) as [Johns Hopkins University](https://www.jhu.edu/)
and formatted according to schema described in Sylak-Glassman et al. (2015).
